Company: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

Drug.@name: Ebola and Dengue virus therapy (nanoparticle formulation), NanoViricides/US Army Medical Research Institute of Infectious Diseases
Drug.Summary: ...polymer, for the potential treatment of viral hemorrhagic fevers, including fevers caused by Ebola and Dengue viruses [845359], [1075467], [1149656], [1202559], [1468593]. In February 2008, positive in vitro Ebola data were reported [877871]; in February 2011, positive in vitro and in vivo Dengue data were presented [1169976]. Company: US Army Medical Research Institute of Infectious Diseases

Drug.@name: ARD-5 (ebola virus infection), University of Iowa
Drug.Summary: University of Iowa is investigating ARD-5, an antibody against VH/VL domain of T cell immunoglobulin and mucin domain (TIM)-1 for the potential treatment of Ebola virus infection. In July 2013, development was ongoing and at that time, the university was seeking to outlicense the antibody [1454998].By July 2013, data had shown that ARD-5 blocked Ebola virus binding and limited the virus infectivity to similar levels as removal of the receptor from the cell surface [1454998].

Drug.@name: small molecule ebola virus entry inhibitors, Harvard University/Harvard University Office of Technology Development
Drug.Summary: Harvard University is investigating small molecule inhibitors of ebola virus (EboV) entry, for the potential treatment of ebola virus infection. In February 2012, development was underway [1455804], [1457347], [1457373]; in July 2013, this was still the case and at that time...of the EboV inhibitor (3.0), was found to be more potent inhibitor of the Lassa fever virus. An additional compound (7) inhibited Lassa fever and Ebola virus infection equally well [1455804], [1457347], [1457373].

Company: Harvard University Office of Technology Development

Drug.@name: filoGP-Fc fusion protein subunit vaccine (ebola virus infection), USAMRIID
Drug.Summary: ...of flio virus glycoprotein (gp) fused to a Fc fragment of human immunoglobulin (filoGp-Fc), for the potential prevention of ebola virus infection [1400816]. In August 2012, preclinical development was ongoing. At that time, NIH Office of Technology Transfer was seeking to outlicense the program [1395222].In April 2011, preclinical data were published. Company: US Army Medical Research Institute of Infectious Diseases

Drug.@name: ebola virus vaccine, Greffex
Drug.Summary: Greffex is investigating a vaccine developed using its GREVAX platform of engineered adenovirus vector as nanoparticle formulation, for the potential prevention or treatment of ebola virus infection [1554539], [1553642], [1554425]. In May 2014, development was ongoing [1554425].

Drug.@name: Ebola vaccine, SKAU Vaccines
Drug.Summary: SKAU Vaccines is investigating a vaccine, based on the company's proprietary Hyper Immunogenic Antigen (HIA) technology, for the potential prevention or treatment of Ebola infection. In February 2013, the vaccine was in preclinical development. At that time, the company was seeking to outlicense the vaccine [1368512].

Drug.@name: rVSV Ebola/Marburg vaccine, Profectus BioSciences
Drug.Summary: ...G-proteins, developed using the company's vesiculovirus‐vectored vaccine delivery platform, for the potential treatment of Ebola and Marburg viruses [1224706], [1286555], [1480508]. In January 2014, preclinical development was ongoing [1515084].In September...EboV and MarV infections [1514939]. By September 2011, preclinical studies had showed that a single injection of the rVSV-Ebola vaccine protected guinea pigs and rhesus macaques against the Zaire strain of Ebola virus [1224706].

Drug.@name: Ebola virus entry inhibitors, Microbiotix

Drug.CompanyOriginator: US Army Medical Research and Materiel Command
Drug.@name: antibody vaccine (ebola virus infection), US Army Medical Research and Materiel Command
Drug.Summary: The US Army Medical Research and Materiel Command is investigating an antibody vaccine, which binds to the virus and inhibits it from spreading, for the potential prevention and treatment of Ebola virus infection. In July 2010, the agency was seeking to outlicense the program [1451538].

CompaniesPrimary.Company: US Army Medical Research and Materiel Command

Drug.@name: trimeric non-degradable protease-resistant D-peptide program (ebola virus infection), Navigen
Drug.Summary: Navigen Pharmaceuticals, is investigating a trimeric non-degradable protease-resistant D-peptides found on ebola viral surface, for the potential prevention of ebola virus. In June 2012, development of the program was ongoing [1394704]; in September 2013, this was still the case [1478837].

Drug.@name: neutralizing antibody (Ebola virus infection), Scripps/USAMRIID
Drug.Summary: The Scripps Research Institute and the US Army Medical Research Institute of Infectious Diseases (USAMRIID) are investigating the antibody 16F6 for the potential treatment of Ebola-Sudan virus infection [1241883], [1242175].In November 2011, data were published showing that the antibody neutralized Sudan virus in vitro and also significantly delayed death in mice infected with the virus [1241883], [1242175].

Company: US Army Medical Research Institute of Infectious Diseases

Drug.@name: vaccine (Marburg/Ebola virus infection), Okairos
Drug.Summary: Okairos, a subsidiary of GlaxoSmithKline, is investigating a vaccine for the potential treatment or prevention of Ebola virus infection [1012432], [1430235]. By April 2009, preclinical studies were ongoing [1012432]. In June 2012, the vaccine was listed as being under preclinical development [1302855]. In May 2013, this was still the case [1430880].

Drug.@name: adenovirus vector 5-based ebola vaccine (oral/tablet), Vaxart
Drug.Summary: Vaxart is investigating an oral tablet formulation of non-replicating adenovirus vector type 5-based vaccine, for the potential treatment or prevention of Ebola virus infection. In January 2013, the vaccine was listed as being in immunogenicity studies [1394706].

Drug.@name: fully human monoclonal antibody therapy (ebola virus infection), Humabs BioMed
Drug.Summary: Humabs BioMed is investigating fully human mAbs for the potential treatment of Ebola virus infection. In April 2012, the antibodies were listed as being in preclinical development [1280479]; in January 2014, this was still the case [1516284]. In April 2012, the company was seeking to outlicense the antibodies [1280479]; in January 2014, this was still the case [1516284].
